reviews.review_msg: Cares about what's important, and that's adding value to your learning experience by teaching you instead of expecting you to memorize. Was a little more disorganized then I'd like, but if you did the assignments, it didn't affect your learning. I would take another course with him because I agree with his teaching philosophy.

Milan is the one prof I would advise to avoid at all costs. He is not an IAT professor, he is a CMPT prof, but honestly, I don't know how he even teaches CMPT courses. I never learned anything in his lectures, he was unaware of the coding syntax, and his code always errored. We never wrote a single functioning coding program in the entire semester.

He hates people who care about the course or want to do good in it. Don't ask questions, don't send emails, don't be inquisitive. He just wants to monologue and get out. I don't even know why he has a teaching job.

Added a midterm abruptly without consulting with the class and undergraduate committee, which resulted in a formal complaint from dozens of students. Was not help at all within or outside of class and absolutely never responded to any emails. Chris was also very condescending to students who asked questions during lecture.

I took IAT 167 during the Fall 2024 semester, and I felt there was a significant lack of communication and support from Professor Shaw. Despite reaching out multiple times for assistance, I did not receive any responses throughout the semester. This made it difficult to clarify concepts or address issues related to the coursework.
Never respond to a single email I sent him! Never tried to help students during semester I only got help from TAs.
